bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Donald H. McLean, July 19, 1935

div1.p: Andrus writes a letter of support for Roger Post Ames and Gustaf E. Lambert, advocating enactment of the bills that would recognize their contributions to the yellow fever commission work and grant pensions.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Donald H. McLean, July 19, 1935
div1.opener:
Andrus letter
Copy
July 19, 1935
FROM GUST LAMBERT
Hon. Donald H. McLean,
House Office Building,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Congressman:
div1.p:
I volunteered for innoculation and had one of the Walter Reed (experimental)
cases of yellow fever.

Furthermore I--a private in the Hospital Corps--was detailed for duty with
Major Reed's Yellow Fever Commission, spent most of my time with Commission
members and-hearing their comments-was thoroughly conversant with developments
and conclusions.

On many occasions I heard Major Reed and Lieutenant Carroll discuss the lack of
fatalities among experimental cases; debate as to whether it was attribuable
to mild attacks, time saved in diagnosis, or extra-ordinary skill in treatment,
and conclude that skill played the larger part.

They often expressed the fear-especially in the earlier stages of experiments-
that a death would cut their work short by cutting off the supply of volunteers.

They referred in terms of the highest praise to Dr. Roger Post Ames and Gust E.
Lambert.

From my personal experience as a patient I can cite examples of the skill and
fidelity of both.

On one occasion I was in great distress. The Doctor who was in charge (during
Dr. Ames own illness with yellow fever) looked at me and walked out without
giving any instructions. The nurse on duty then awakened Lambert (who was on
night duty and asleep during the day). Lambert examined and catheterized me
which probably saved my life.

On another occasion a large abscess which-according to the official report of
my case-was “retarding recovery”-was given no attention by the doctor above re-
ferred to. Lambert reported the condition to Dr. Ames who was carried on his bed
about a quarter mile to me where he lanced the abscess. (He, too, was suffering
with yellow fever).

I consider it a very grave injustice that-during his lifetime-Dr. Ames received
no recognition for having played one of the most important parts in ridding the
world of yellow fever. I sincerely hope that belated recognition may be granted
his widow and beg that you use your influence to secure enactment in the House
of the legislation to that end which passed the Senate as Senate Bill Number 1850.

I most sincerely hope that the government may reward Gust E. Lambert for the risk
he ran in voluntarily nursing ALL the Walter Reed experimental cases of yellow
fever, and for the skill, fidelity and sympathy he gave to his work. I hope this
recognition may be given this broken, crippled man while he is alive to appre-
ciate it. To this end I beg your sincere efforts to secure enactment of H. R.
No. 4030.
